bibl.title: Letter from Lunsford D. Fricks to Henry Rose Carter, September 14, 1922

div1.p: Fricks quotes a letter he received from Barber that says Chaara foetida is not suitable as food for mosquito larvae.

div1.head: Letter from Lunsford D. Fricks to Henry Rose Carter, September 14, 1922
div1.opener:
OFFICE OF
MALARIA INVESTIGATIONS
FIELD HEADQUARTERS
ROOM 17, COURTHOUSE
N. M. C.
Lamades
Plants
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
MEMPHIS, TENN.
September 14, 1922
JG
Chara foetida
Asst. Surgeon-General H. R. Carter,
U. S. Public Health Service
2121 California Street, N.W.,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Doctor:
div1.p:
Replying to your recent inquiry relative
to Chara foetida, I am sending you herewith a note
prepared by Dr. Barber in reply to the same inquiry
which I made of him:

“Here is all I know about Chara.
I have read the Spanish reports re Chara foetida,
or at least one of them. In 'this country breed-
ing of anopheles will go on in the presence of
our species of Characeae - I have made several
observations. But crushed Nitella seems to have
some larvicidal power (experiment done at Brewton)
Metz reports that Chara is unsuitable as food for
larvae -other species of plants serving very well for
that purpose. I should think, judging from what
I know of the distribution of Characeae in this
country, that it probably would prove more diffi-
cult to keep the pond stocked with Chara than to
get rid of the mosquitoes by some other means.
In rice field Chara found recently in one large
patch, but anopheles breeding going on neverthe-
less. (Same true of several species of blue green
algae this region). It is doubtful if any larvi-
cide prepared from chara would be cheaper than
those already known or more efficient. But it will
be worth while to get identifications of our
Characeae and make some observations - but not in-
vesting too much time in it.”
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, L. D. Fricks, Surgeon,
Medical Officer inCharge.
